segments.text: As I was saying, the department did purchase a birdshot, which at 2 to 3 feet is deadly, but at 20 to 30 feet is not.
And at least at that point, we had something as an alternative between the use of a wooden stick and an absolute deadly force.
We still do not have it.
Rubber bullets are available and so forth.
And certainly chemical agents are available as a means to try to affect crowd control.

But we still do not have even developed what I suppose one would call weapon systems that are useful in that kind of situation in the sense of being injurious enough to get someone's attention, but not so injurious as to maim or kill.
OK.
Did the increase of blacks and women in the force have any impact on crowd control?
MR. No, not appreciably.
Not appreciably.
People, I don't care what your background is, what your ideology is, when you get in a crowd control situation and you're over there in that uniform, you're a uniform, period.
The amount of solidarity and unity is just absolutely as strong as you can imagine in that sort of situation.
Your life depends upon the backing of someone next to you and vice versa, and it just doesn't make much difference.
I had read an article in the U.S. News and World Report where Cleveland hired some black officers to go into the ghetto situations, and they said it didn't work.
Didn't, no.
In fact, I would speculate that in some situations you might aggravate it in the sense that...
those officers might be less sympathetic or less tolerant than what white officers might be.
That's pure speculation, I hasten to add, but it's not going to make an enormous amount of difference.
Was crowd control or maybe just crime itself, general crime, an issue in the 1968 campaign?
And if so, what were Nixon and Johnson's stance on the issue?
Well, it certainly was an issue in the 1968 campaign.
Those were certainly understatements, say, turbulent years of the United States.
And looking back, I don't think that Nixon, clearly he campaigned on very vague promises with regard to both what he would do about situations in the black ghettos and with regard to the Vietnam War.

But Lyndon Johnson had the unfortunate experience of being president at the wrong time, analogous to Herbert Hoover, who didn't create the Depression but happened to come into office right before it hit.
And that was the situation with Lyndon Johnson.
I have a great deal of respect and admiration for Lyndon Johnson as a president.
And I think he did probably as credible a job as anyone in that office at that particular time could have done.
Now, he had to withdraw from the election.
He chose to withdraw, and I think he would have lost the election had he run against Nixon, because people were upset with the situation and were going to vote for a change, period.
And it didn't matter.
I don't believe it mattered what the agenda of change would have been.
They were voting for an agenda of change, period, or for change, period.
Yes, it was very much an issue.
And the Democratic Party was hurt at that particular time through its identity with social change, with social activism, and so forth.
And the mood of the country was a mood of, let's get a handle on this.
Let's back off.
Because in every instance, of course, it's extreme situations which make the headlines.
It's extreme situations which drew the attention of the national news media.
And in that sense, the Johnson administration was characterized as having failed to maintain social control.
One of the things that's relatively confusing about the era is how the polarization tended to group
several issues together which were in essence unrelated.
The black ghetto riots, the Vietnam War protest,

The increase, the skyrocketing crime rate, which really took off about 1963, 1962, 1963, and it was precipitously climbing all during that era, all got wrapped up in this law and order issue, that there was a lack of respect for authority, that we need to enforce the laws, that we need to maintain order.
And three, what in effect, were diverse issues
I won't say unrelated to one another or certain relationships, but three distinctly different issues tended to be grouped together.
And in that sense, people would end up voting for order, not voting against the Vietnam protests, not voting against the plight of black ghetto residents, but simply voting for maintenance of order.
That's what they wanted to do.
What do you think of Nixon's law and order campaign?
I know you said he was pretty vague about it.
And was it carried out after he was elected?
And how did it have an effect, if any, on crowd control?
Well, the law and order campaign, like every law and order campaign at the federal level, is as phony as a $3 bill.
Law enforcement in this country is fragmented.
It's certainly coordinated effort is not possible beyond the state level.
And even at that level, extremely difficult to amount any coordinated effort.
So we get president after president in this sense.
The issue of crime control first came up the 1964 elections.
Prior to that, one is hard pressed to find reference to crime as an issue, a national political issue.
And we have presidents running on a law and order ticket, law and order platform.
There isn't very much they can do to affect law and order.
It's a state and local issue.

Now, the one thing that was visibly done was the creation of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration during the Johnson administration, which Nixon continued, which provided federal aid to local law enforcement programs for
innovation and development.
That aid was specifically, there were specific provisions which prohibited local, state and local agencies from supplanting endeavors that they were now supporting with state or local money.
So you couldn't take the federal money and do something you were now doing with state money.
You had to do something new with federal money.

And that was a tremendous boon to law enforcement in this country, to develop a sophistication in law enforcement, to virtually catapulting, I don't think it's an overstatement to say, catapulting the police finally into the 20th century.
Whenever prior to that, very antiquated operations
did not take advantage of either recruitment selection of high quality personnel or the technology that's available to them.
So the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, which died during the Carter administration, was certainly the primary factor.
And we still have a residual of that, by the way.
The National Institute of Justice still exists.
And just a month ago, President Reagan signed what's now called the Justice Assistance Act, which will
in effect, resurrect LEAA.
They don't want to say that because... See, one of the problems with LEAA politically was that crime did not go down.
A lot of money was pumped in.
At the peak in 1973, a billion dollar appropriation to LEAA, which went to state and local government to help in crime control.
But the crime rates didn't drop.
And so the program was regarded as a failure.
Well,
it would take a long time to get off onto this tangent, but the effect of that sort of thing is going to take years to really be demonstrated.
And federal money was dumped on a problem, and whenever solutions weren't forthcoming within four or five years, there was disillusionment set in at the federal level.
That was the primary, the whole product of the riots which started out in the Watts section of Los Angeles with the
Vietnam protests and focusing national attention on the police and getting the police into the CBS evening news was undoubtedly and unquestionably the omnibus Safe Streets and Crime Control Act.
And the only measure in that act which made any difference at all was the federal assistance, the money that came down.
The other provisions are empty fluff.
Can you cite anything in particular of why it didn't work for our lawyers?
on the federal assistance?
Well, crime...
The difference between the best case and the worst case in terms of what we can do with structured societal response to crime is probably not all that great.
First of all, crime is primarily a product of social conditions.
So if in the...
I suspect that in terms of the best case...
the most effective, most efficient criminal justice system response possible probably makes no more than a 20% difference in the crime rate.
Now, it took time.
When that money first came down, you literally didn't know what to do with it.
I was on the Law Enforcement Training Council during that period of time when the money really started flowing, 1971.
We had representatives.
It was dispersed to all the states, and then the state could disperse within.
It was a block grant program, it was called.
So the state would get a block grant, $20 million, and then the state would disperse it to local agencies within that state, and it would be a state agency that was responsible for that.
Representatives of the state agency came out and visited the Law Enforcement Training Council and said, come up with something.
Give us some training programs.
We've got about $300,000 here that we need to spend, and we're just going to go back.
And so we literally invented training programs, quick and dirty, to get the money out.
It took time to develop the sophistication.
It took time.
You didn't have in law enforcement anybody with college degrees at that time.
When I went on the Lansing Police Department in 1967 with a baccalaureate degree, I was the first individual ever to go on that department, a $200 million department that had a college degree.
And in fact, you didn't tell anybody about it.
You kept quiet about it.
And so you just simply didn't have the sophistication.
You didn't have the infrastructure in place to spend the money effectively.
About the time that the money dried up, the Carter administration, we finally were in a position to spend it well.
And I suspect if the money starts flowing again in substantial amounts through the new Justice Assistance Act, we'll do a much better job of spending it this time than what we did the last time.
OK.
We've already talked a little bit about the tough position the policemen are in.
What were the police force's feelings during the 60s towards being ostracized for alleged brutality and breakout riots?
And did these feelings have an effect on their performance?
Yes.
Police officers were very resentful of the hostility that was generated against them.
They truly felt like that they had behaved in a very reserved way.
which in the vast majority of instances did occur.
They felt like they were being made scapegoats.
They felt like they were doing a basic duty in terms of maintenance of order and were being criticized for that.
And it had an effect on performance.
It had an effect both in terms of your reaction
a riot line and in your daily contact with citizens.
I think that was an era which was very unpleasant in a sense of police feelings of hostility towards the community.
You'd see that, you'd stop someone on a traffic stop who had hair below their ears, and boy,
Unpleasant exchanges may not have been inevitable, but occurred at a high percentage of the time.
And the police certainly instigated much of that.
Walk up and say, OK, dirtbag, give me your driver's license.
You're not going to have a pleasant contact after that.
And so that resentment was manifested both in riot situations and in daily contacts.
A lot of ill feelings at that particular time.
How did these feelings affect the performance when they went into the situation?
Were they less hesitant to bring out force?
Yes, I think they were less hesitant to bring out force.
They made many unnecessary arrests.
They generated hostility where none necessarily had been generated.
We have...
strong commitment to a civilian police system in this country.
I believe very, very strongly in making a civilian police system and recognize that on a worldwide basis, a number of police agencies are not civilian in the sense that we think of it as civilian.
very closely aligned to military.
Even in some other democracies, they are very closely aligned to military and, in fact, train with military and interchange, in some cases, interchange in terms of officer corps and the like.
The problem with the disturbances during that era is it militarized the police.
It put them in a role of a military force rather than a civilian force.
And the police are not prepared to deal with that.
That's a good way to put it.
They're just not prepared to deal with that.
Police in the United States are, in effect, civilians in uniform.
And as long as you maintain that,
that both legal and psychological approach to the job, you'll do well.

When you start thinking of yourself as an occupying military force, as the police were in the black ghettos during that period of time, in situations in St. Louis, in Los Angeles, even in Detroit, where
They wouldn't respond to a call, a domestic dispute, in certain areas, certain blocks, without sending four officers.
So you send four officers in on a husband-wife dispute where you've got to call a referee.

Well, you show up with four individuals, and yet the character of that situation is going to change immediately into a confrontation, hostile situation, just by the nature of you walking the door with four guys facing some
husband who's having a, and he's maybe half drunk, usually is, but having a dispute with his wife, and you're not going to sit down and do social counseling and mediation with four officers there.
Okay.
Is riot control, I'm trying to get what you think about it, is riot control a police force's job, military, or both?

well it should first be the police force's job despite this may sound contradictory despite everything i've said about the police are basically civilians the police basically are untrained or unprepared to deal with with riots we have in fact an absolutely outstanding record in the united states the police dealing with riots from the perspective of civilians not getting hurt and by and large the police have managed to control civil disturbance in this country without hurting civilians i think that's part of
Despite the ineptitude, despite the lack of equipment, despite their own psychological, their own fear in those situations, the police, by and large, have behaved as civilians.
And the few instances we've brought military in have not
gone well.
The amount of force used is typically far more than is necessary.
Realize the police have to walk back to that neighborhood the next day.
They've got to deal with those people on a one-to-one basis.
And they are much more hesitant to club somebody over the head or to shoot at somebody because the next day they could be shooting back at them.
And they're going to use a whole lot more restraint.
No, I think the police, you only call in the military when it's virtually totally out of control and the civilian police are no longer able to handle it at all
And that would be absolutely a last resort, including the National Guard, by the way, which is probably the worst to call in of anybody.
Okay.
When you say they, in the past, have a really good history, that's comparing it to other countries?
Yes, right.
That's in, yeah, it's in contrast to even other democracies where the police have reacted with much greater force and there have been many more, much more extensive injuries ensued.
Okay.
What a,
What impact over the 60s was media?
Well, there's no doubt that media coverage of these events escalates the violence, escalates the disturbances.
I'm not proposing news blackouts, but certainly it is helpful to have voluntary restraint on the part of the media in coverage of certain of these events.
a minor disturbance at a city park can become a neighborhood-wide riot if the cameras are immediately there and if you're broadcasting it on the evening news and so forth.
I think that what's necessary is restraint on the part of the media whenever disturbances are still in progress.
Now, once...
Once they've subsided, then certainly the media can, I wouldn't propose for a minute that we don't provide full coverage.
But I do believe it's wise to maintain some restraint while things are in progress.
It does incite.
It does draw individuals, more individuals, into the situation.
And also, do cameras have a strong effect on how brutal the police are going to be when they know that there's a camera right there?
No, I don't believe the cameras have a mitigating effect on police brutality.
No.
The psychology of that situation, by the time an officer loses control and starts wailing with a nightstick, it doesn't matter if you've got 50 TV cameras focused in on that officer.
He is...
the kind of instigation, the kind of fear that's beget that.
In his mind, he is being justified in what he's doing, and therefore the fact that you're taping it isn't making any difference.
It's not a situation where he's trying to commit a deviant act that he knows he'll be sanctioned for.
From the perspective of that officer, he's justified in doing what he's doing.
Okay.
Why did Hubert Humphrey order an FBI inquiry on the Battle of Chicago?
Well...
And what came about that inquiry?
I don't recall the precise results of that inquiry.
Certainly no one that I recall was ever sanctioned in the city of Chicago for anything they did during the Democratic Convention riots.
Not one officer.
I would defend the actions of the Chicago police as human beings.
I would not defend their actions as an organizational entity, as a unit of government.
In that sense, Humphrey's call for an inquiry was undoubtedly justified to the extent that such inquiry investigates
the appropriateness of organizational response, which was needed.
Realize you had Mayor Daley in Chicago at the time.
And Daley was a classic law and order and had made comments in the months prior to that during some of the ghetto disturbances in Chicago.
And this is where you get this bleeding of one incident into another.
During the ghetto disturbances in Chicago, he had made a public comment on television
I want my officers to shoot to kill arsonists and shoot to maim looters.
Well, looters are, for God's sakes, I don't want to sound sexist, but women and children out there looting.
There's an excellent, Joseph Lombard's book, The New Centurions, has a chapter or two devoted to, which is quasi-autobiographical, by the way, has a chapter or two devoted to
the Watts Riot.

And there's an excellent scenario where a young sergeant ends up taking control of a platoon of seven or eight individuals, and there's a warehouse, and there's individuals in the warehouse, and he gets caught up in the role, and he surrounds the warehouse, and he orders them to surrender over the bullhorn, and then they come parading out.
And I can't quote it exactly, but Wambaugh does a number in terms of, the first one out was an old man with a strong limp and an old battered trench coat.
The second was a
a middle-aged woman who weighed over 250 pounds, and a third one.
And he goes on like that until you get these looters, these rebels.
I'm trying to look for the right word here.

uh instigators of rebellion and and so forth and what what of course the the scenario is uh he's got his military strike force there and he's got a pathetic lot of people uh that he's surrounded in order to come out with their hands up and uh
As the scenario goes in the chapter, the sergeant shakes his head and walks away.
The officers are left standing there wondering what to do.
They stand around for about five minutes, and they all walk away, and the looters walk away.
I cite that to you because it's a telling situation in terms of what you have.
We have never been so polarized in this country that we didn't identify with one another.

I read in the U.S. News report, U.S. News and World Report back in 1964, that the Army's approach to crowd control was to first show force, second, ask rioters to disperse, three, be in the crowd to disperse, four, use high-pressure water hoses, five, use tear gas, six, fire at leaders, and then seven, fire at everybody else.
What do you think about this approach, and has it changed?
And if it has changed, what are the reasons for change?
First of all, the assumption is when you start with a show of force, the assumption in terms of general operating procedures is that you already have a crowd which is considered out of control.
So preceding that, what you generally have is minimum show of force as long as the crowd is peaceful.
You don't want to instigate them.
In terms of that sequence, once a crowd is out of control, I don't think it's changed.
That primarily is the technique that's recommended.
The only thing I'm not quite sure of, and I don't think you'll find in any police department training manual, is the shooting at.
You're only going to return fire, particularly when dealing with a crowd.

The only variant of that would be that rather than shooting leaders, arresting leaders is generally regarded as a good tactic to go in and attempt to arrest the leaders early on if the other tactics don't work.
I also read where a mayor advocated a permanence to stop riots, and it worked for him.
He was quoted as saying, meet force with superior force from the outset.
to warn people, no mercy on the lawless.
Do you think it just takes a certain kind of crowd for this to work?
Or do you think this, do you totally disagree with this?
I simply disagree with it.
Gentlemen, no mercy on the lawless.
Those kind of statements are good, classic situation of law and order rhetoric.
that out on the street doesn't get translated.
It just loses translation out on the street.
You've got the classic picture, the photograph that made all the papers in the late 1960s during the Newark riots of the police officer in Newark bearing down with a shotgun.
You don't see what he's shooting at, but the commentary was he shot and killed a 12-year-old boy running from a liquor store.
That's, you know, no mercy for the lawless.
We have never had justice without mercy.
We've always had mercy and justice.
I just disagree totally with that.
I think that the business of showing force is fine, the business of enforcing the law within the limits of what you're able to do out and out, the turmoil of a riot situation.
And there are real limits to that.
I don't know.
How much good do you do by arresting somebody running away from the store with a gun?
A woman who lives in a black ghetto running in, grabbing some dresses, running away to the store, and so you'd effect an arrest.
And during the setting of a ghetto riot, whenever everybody's looting or TVs are being carried away, I don't know that you accomplish a thing.
Were there some changes in technique and equipment that made the riot situations more violent?
And about when were these changes made?
I don't recall any changes that I would characterize as making pariah situations more violent.
And as a point in fact, I think if changes were made, they'd probably decrease the amount of violence, not aggravated it.
Do you recall any that made them less violent?
I think to the extent that the police were prepared to deal with, had some sort of a backup in terms of use of force,
the bird shot as a case in point, for example, I think that the police were more confident.
The police were less afraid that they would have to use deadly force and therefore have deadly force used on them.
Certainly in terms of the distribution of walkie-talkies, believe it or not, to each officer, which were just being distributed at that time.
Now, in a ghetto situation, that's very important to you because you're in communication with police

with other officers and therefore again you're less afraid you're less likely to start shooting in a situation where you feel threatened those things more than more than gas grenades or pepper foggers or that sort of thing really those those items were used relatively seldom professor joseph layman of cal berkeley said in a democratic society the police must be concerned with what
with doing what is most consistent with the least amount of force.
How do you feel about this statement?
Yes, I would agree with that.
We never enforce all the law all the time.
And that simply carries through to a riot situation.
In a riotous situation, it doesn't always pay to make an arrest, even if you see a violation.
You use the least amount of force to affect control, to maintain order.
The law is not an end in and of itself.
It's a means to an end.
The end is maintaining order.
And enforcement of the law is the best means.
In one situation, fine, but in other situations, it may not be.
And that's certainly true in riot or disturbance situations.
How much of a part did police dogs play in the change over the decades?
Not very much.
I don't recall a dog being used in the state of Michigan during any of the disturbances.
And my memory just is not good enough to tell you whether they may have been used in disturbances elsewhere.
The image of the dogs being used in Birmingham, Alabama during the civil rights demonstrations had an enormous impact.

police were in fact many departments simply have policies that forbid even dog even departments that have dogs have policies that forbid they're using them in crowd control situations because they are so inflammatory and I were I a police chief I would absolutely forbid a dog from being used in a crowd control situation no no reason for yes right and at that in fact that era
Steve had really hurt what is otherwise an effective law enforcement tool, the use of dogs.
And we're still recoiling from that era whenever dogs were used for riot control in Birmingham and probably elsewhere.
I don't remember.
I remember specifically Birmingham, Alabama.
And that generated such hostility, such resentment towards police dogs that many agencies don't have them yet that should have them for purposes of tracking, for purposes of going in a building.
We have a burglar hiding.
And locating the burglar, it's a lot safer for the officers.
It's a lot safer for the burglar, in a sense.
He doesn't get a trigger-happy officer blowing him away, then he sees a shadow.
But departments are hesitant to have dogs because of that riot control imagery of dogs.
When was that taking place?
And when did the dogs were?
That was early, early 60s.
Yeah, those civil rights demonstrations were early 60s, particularly in Birmingham.
And by the time you had the full-scale late 60s disturbances, I don't recall dogs being used.
OK. You've already touched on a few of the techniques, the equipment for crowd control.
With the increased government spending on research for crowd control devices, such as a bubbly machine, an instant banana peel, rubber bullet, die-bearing dart,
Were they used and were they effective?
They weren't used in the late 60s.
I think most of that technology is post-1970 technology, and so by and large were not used in the 1960s.
And I have reservations about how effective any of it will be.
You've got to have it at the right place at exactly the right time, and it's very difficult in some cases to do that.
I've gotten it out of an article dated in 67, but I guess that was just enough.
Maybe the testing stages.
Well, I stand corrected then.
They may have had them.
I just don't recall them being available to any agency.
I was on the Law Enforcement Training Council, as you recall, in 1971, and we developed the training modules for civil disturbances then.
And I don't remember an agency in the state of Michigan that had any of those devices.
Again, they may have, and I just wasn't aware of it, but they certainly weren't widespread use.
So these newfangled devices didn't change any technique or anything?
No.
They weren't even used?
No.
Could you please compare the differences in controlling a crowd in 64 and more than 74?
If there are any differences.
I know you mentioned that psychology was one of the biggest changes over the 60s, whereas technique wasn't quite as much.
I think we learned, I think that decade taught the police to act with reservation, no matter what the provocation.
That's the primary thing we learned.
Now, even given that,
You had a situation in Austin in the last 12 months where you had officers getting carried away and whaling with the nightsticks.
But the difference there is that the minute the subject was subdued, the nightsticks quit flying, and it did not spread.
The anger did not spread among other officers to the point where you had 40 or 50 nightsticks whaling.
The primary issue was learning the lesson
that you're not going to win by clubbing somebody in the head.
You're going to lose.
The media's going to rack you.
You're going to be criticized.
The police chief's going to lose his job.
That you're going to lose.
Out on that situation, I don't care what the provocation, you hold your temper.
Now, that's the lesson that was really learned.
And the equipment and the formations and the techniques are all secondary to that.
Okay.
A hypothetical situation today and now, say you were chief of police and...
there was a crowd, potential riot situation, what would your plan of action be?
Well, I think first of all to have a minimum show of force until it was inevitable that violence was going to occur.
When violence occurred, then move out in force and immediately arrest the leaders, the agitators of the crowd, remove them from the scene.
Don't make mass arrests, if you can avoid it at all.
Don't make mass arrests.
Go in and grab four or five.
And then attempt to split that crowd into small groups.
Mob psychology is very real.
People in that large group and the anonymity that comes from being in that large group.
people really do behave differently than what they will as individuals.
To the extent that you can get them in small groups, to the extent that you can get them isolated, they'll start behaving as individuals again.
And that's the primary tactic to be used.
Probably the last question would be, I know crowd control riots, like you said, are a big issue now because there are very few of them.
How much research for crowd control is going on today and what do you see in the future?
I'm not aware of any research going on in crowd control right now.
There's certainly not in terms of, in general in police circles, any research going on in crowd control.
We have, relatively speaking, very effective agents for fraud control right now.
The banana peel of the types of agents and so forth are fine, but good old CS Gas has always done it for us.
You hit someone with a crab with a pepper fogger, and they're going to move.
in terms of controlling the crowd, other than dealing with the psychology of crowd control, equipment is not the answer.
And we know, in terms of the approach to crowds, what the best police psychological approach is.
When we get to equipment,
then if you're going to have to disperse that crowd of equipment, you gas them, pure and simple.
And it's highly effective.
It works.
They're going to move.
They're going to run.
And when they start running, you split.
You divide them.
You plan ahead of time so that the...
either with wedges of officers or by the natural configuration of the area or whatever, to start splitting that crowd into smaller groups.
And when you do that, you'll get control of it again.
It's only in a large mob that things really get out of control.
And I don't foresee any extensive amount of attention being paid to this.
I don't know if you've ever experienced being hit with tear gas or not, but one time around, it makes a believer out of you.
That stuff stings, your eyes, you no longer can see, your eyes are watering so bad you can't see, you choke, you gag, and you don't sit there next to a gas bomb and look at it.
You move whenever it hits.
That's very effective.
No long-term injuries result from that.
I know it has a bad reputation, but after all, at that point you're talking about
We're talking about trying to use force, which isn't going to maim or kill.
And that is effective.
Is there any other comments you'd like to add about the questions or anything about this interview?
Do you feel we got a full one?
I think we did a pretty reasonable job.
You did a very thorough job in the interview.
My compliments to you in terms of covering the issues that exist with regard to the problem.
I would just, I would add something as just a matter of underscoring that I've already said, and that is that the primary dynamic is police fear.

And if you can prevent the police, to the extent, you can't prevent the police from being afraid, but to the extent you can give police confidence, you'll maintain structured, reasoned response to crowd control.
When the police are, when the police go out of control is when the police fear is out of control.
I don't think the Chicago police on that Wednesday night in Chicago
rioted because they hated the demonstrators.
I think they rioted because they were afraid for their personal safety and for the safety of their families.
And they were going to strike out at somebody.
They were going to show who was in charge.
A very effective technique for a group that wants to form a rebellion in this country is to personalize the police.
Start calling them at home.
Start leaving something in their mailbox on their doorstep.
And I'll guarantee you, you will get a
violent police reaction when you do that.
Yes, that's a lot of wine.
Thank you very much, Dr. Hoover.
No problem, Steve.
You really did do a good job.
